title: Wisdom of the Last Farmer
description: This book is ripe with fruit metaphors
quote: Imagine if politicians could adopt a duct-tape work ethic and be able to admit it whenever they don't have the answer - they could rever to duct-tape solutions, knowing that they're not perfect, but at least they're trying.
author: David Mas Masumoto

title: Small Gods
description: I think Neil Gaiman took a page out of this book. This may not be the best, but it's the first.
quote: `Are you all philosophers?` said Brutha. The one called Xeno stepped forward, adjusting the hang of his toga. `That's right`, he said. `We're philosophers. We think, therefore we am.`
author: Terry Prachett

title: The Complete Sherlock Holmes
description: Sherlock is truly the first superhero—and the best.
quote: The game is afoot.
author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle

title: Sucker's Portfolio
description: I bet Vonnegut would give this an even lower grade.
author: Kurt Vonnegut

title: The Trial
description: I'm not sure what happened. I knew, but then things changed.
quote: Next time I come here," he said to himself, "I must either bring sweets with me to make them like me or a stick to hit them with.
author: Franz Kafka

title: Mythos
description: I've not read another survey of Greek mythology, but if I did I bet it wouldn't be as good as this.
quote: Gaia visited her daughter Mnemosyne, who was busy being unpronounceable.
author: Stephen Fry

title: Consider the Lobster
description: He gets into it. He really gets into it.
quote: Truly decent, innocent people can be taxing to be around.
author: David Foster Wallace

title: Devil in the White City
description: Two fascinating, yet quite separate, tales are chopped up and put in the same sausage casing.
quote: Menu: Hard boiled potatoes, a la Irish Village. Stuffed ostrich, a la Ostrich Farm. Boiled camel humps, a la Cairo street. Monkey stew, a la Hagenbeck. Fricasse of reindeer, a la Lapland. Fried snowballs, a la Ice Railway. Sandwiches (assorted), especially prepared by the Leather Exhibit.
author: Erik Larson

title: The Visual display of Quantitative Information
description: This book takes a dive into the analysis of human perception, through the lens of analyzing large data sets.
quote: Graphical excellence is that which gives to the viewer the greatest number of ideas in the shortest time with the least ink in the smallest space.
author: Edward R. Tufte

title: Manufacturing Consent
description: It really opened my eyes, and often closed them.
quote: A propaganda model suggests that the "societal purpose" of the media is to inculcate and defend the ecnomic, social, and political agenda of privileged groups that dominate the domestic society and state. The media serve this purpose in many ways: through selection of topics, distribution of concerns, framing of issues, filtering of information, enphasis and tone, and by keeping debate within the bounds of acceptable promises.
author: Edward S. Herman & Noam Chomsky

title: Dead Wake
subtitle: The Last Crossing of the Lusitania
description: While a work of non-fiction, this reads like a masterfully composed novel. Larson’s incredibly detailed descriptions of weather, clothing, and interactions gave me a sense of being on the ship from the moment it left port in Manhattan to the moment the last radio antenna dipped below the surface of the Celtic Sea.
quote: Any other man would have found this scene terrifying. Brooks was entranced. He saw the body of the torpedo moving well ahead of the wake, through water he described as being ‘a beautiful green.’ The torpedo ‘was covered with a silvery phosphorescence, you might term it, which was caused by the air escaping from the motors.’ He said, ‘It was a beautiful sight.’
author: Erik Larson

title: The Long Dark Tea-Time of the Soul
description: Other than not having a likable protagonist (or any other characters), having a weak plot, and being essentially a weak proto-American Gods, it's okay I guess.
quote: The sun crept slowly across the bedclothes, as of nervous of what it might find amongst them, slunk down the side of the bed, moved in a rather started way across some objects it encountered on the floor, toyed nervously with a couple of motes of dust, lit briefly on a stuffed fruit bat hanging in the corner, and fled.
author: Douglas Adams

title: Dirk Gently’s Holistic Detective Agency
description: If you've watched the eponymous show, then you should have very little idea of what is happening in this book.
quote: Well, said Reg, in a loudly confidential whisper, as if introducing the subject of nipple-piercing in a nunnery.
author: Douglas Adams

title: Origin Story
description: From the Big Bang there have been a few major event thresholds: the formation of stars, the chemical complexity of planets, the origin of life, the development of civilization. All of these are connected by harnessing energy, increasing complexity, and paying entropy.
author: David Christian

title: Mother Night
description: Howard W. Campbell, an infamous Nazi propagandists, tells his story from in prison in Israel. Is he guilty of war crimes or an unappreciated American spy? Maybe both. But when someone steals your light bulbs, what is left to guide you?
quote: You said he was arrested and tried? / And shot. / For plagiarism? / For originality. Plagiarism is the silliest of misdemeanors. What harm is there in writing what's already been written? Real originality is a capital crime, often calling for cruel and unusual punishment in advance of the coup de grace.
author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr

title: The Uninhabitable Earth
subtitle: Life After Warming
description: If you’re going to read this book of what will very likely come to be, try to find a way to keep your anxiety in check. It will raise. It should raise.
quote: The ravings [of the Book of Revelation], the inescapable sourcebook for Western anxiety about the end of the world, have so predominated the Western dreamscape—becoming something like the Gnostic wallpaper of our bourgeois inner lives.
author: David Wallace-Wells

title: The Lord of the Rings
description: The words are poetry. Every time I read this book I fall more deeply in love with the world The Professor created.
quote: The enemy? His sense of duty was no less than yours, I deem. You wonder what his name is, where he came from. And if he was really evil at heart. What lies or threats led him on this long march from home. If he would not rather have stayed there in peace. War will make corpses of us all.
author: J.R.R. Tolkien

title: Lies My Teacher Told Me
subtitle: Everything Your American History Textbook Got Wrong
description: Loewen asserts that American history textbooks, rather than teach American history, serve essentially to create nationalist citizens who are taught not to think critically, that America is the greatest republic in the history of the world, and that our country has done no wrong.
quote: Of course the people do not want war...But, after all, it is the leaders of the country who determine the policy, and it is always a simple matter to drag the people along, whether it is a democracy, a fascist dictatorship, a parliament, or a communist dictatorship. Voice or no voice, the people can always be brought to the bidding of the leaders. That is easy. All you have to do is tell them that they are being attacked and denounce the pacifists for lack of patriotism. -German field marshall Hermann Goering, Nuremberg, April 18, 1946
author: James W. Loewen

title: The Spell of the Sensuous
description: Abram considers the development of writing to be the single most influencing factor as to why moder-day humans are less connected to the natural world than were our ancestors and he gives some pretty great examples along the way.
quote: Two of these Winds, often spoken of as Little Winds, are believed to be the individual’s “means of knowing.” These two Little Winds linger within the spiraling folds of our two ears, and it is from there that they offer guidance to us, alerting us to near and distant difficulties, helping us to plan and to make choices. When a Navajo person finds himself thinking in words, this is said to be the voice of one or both of these two Little Winds speaking into his ears.
author: David Abram

title: Beowulf
subtitle: Translation & Commentary
description: I don’t doubt that this poem was more transformative than most books I’ve read. I don’t doubt that I am not in touch enough with the nuances of the Christian domination of the Nordic peoples to grasp the nuanced criticism of the new religion. Nonetheless, this text comes off more as a bad knock off of Tolkien or Prachett, rather than a predecessor to it.
author: J.R.R. Tolkien

title: The Pillowman
description: A man made of pillows helps children think of clever ways to die. A little girl wants to be Jesus, so she gets crucified. A funny little piggy gets a new coat of paint.
author: Martin McDonagh

title: Manage Your Day to Day
description: This is essentially a collection of fleshed out platitudes. It's all great advice, but I prefer a bit of meat with my advice. I guess that's why I read fiction.
author: 99U

title: Faust
description: Faust is a jerk and definitely deserves the hell he signed up for. Mephistopheles is badass, but his great plans keep getting foiled by that pesky God character.
quote: There was a king once reigning / who had a big black flea / and loved him past explaining / as his own son were he / he called his man of stitches / the tailor came straightaway / here, measure the lad for breeches / and measure his coat, I say!
author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

title: The Corrections
description: The 90's are over. The bubble is bursting. The leather is getting smelly. The ribs are getting cold. The wound is bleeding. The ship is sinking. Christmas is still there.
quote: She was seventy-five and she was going to make some changes in her life.
author: Jonathan Franzen

title: The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle
description: First his cat goes missing. Then his wife. He goes on a hunt to find them both. He makes a lot of food, drinks a lot of beer, and goes down a well. It was intriguing and the historical bits were quite good, but I was never truly entranced. Still, it was better than being skinned alive.
author: Haruki Murakami

title: Player Piano
description: A man who is a bit bored with all of the automation that he helped create decides to buy a farm...and lead a revolution.
quote: He could see the device now—sort of an Iron Maiden, without the spikes, and of course, electronic, of course, that would grasp a little girl firmly in St. Louis, and eject her into the arms of relatives at Poughkeepsie.
author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr

title: The Princess Bride
description: The Spaniard, the giant, the pirate, and the princess. You know the story. But did you that it's all true history? There is even a museum in Florin. There is a lot you didn't know.
quote: Life isn’t fair, it’s just fairer than death, that’s all.
author: William Goldman

title: Modernist Cuisine V.2
subtitle: Techniques
description: Detailed descriptions of the science and applications of modernist food techniques like Combi ovens, sous vide, and liquid nitrogen.
author: Nathan Myhrvold

title: Discworld: The Colour of Magic
description: The writing is as sharp as an old banana isn't and the world is as well forged as a Celebrimborian ring or an Arthur Dentian sandwich.
quote: Withel said nothing. Being Ymor's right-hand man was like being gently flogged to death with scented bootlaces.
author: Terry Prachett

title: I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream
description: I see no hope in this writing, but I see marvelous malevolent machines, soul sucking slots, and daring delusional dragon slayers; and that's not so bad.
author: Harlan Ellison

title: How Music Works
description: David shares some of his past and some of this thoughts on how music works, and sometimes doesn't.
author: David Byrne

title: Pachyderive
description: Post-WWII. A woman lost in a dream searches through a surreal hospital in search of her injured husband.
author: Frederik Peeters

title: Chess
description: A savant and a man tortured by Nazis face off in a many layered chess game.
author: Stephan Zweig

title: The End of Trust
description: A collection of essays on topics of technology, surveillance, and trust.
author: Electronic Frontier Foundation

title: Ready Player One
description: It's a dead mans party, who could ask for more? Everybody's coming, leave your body at the door.
author: Ernest Cline

title: Breakfast of Champions
description: Vonnegut meditates. Words are without meaning. People are without purpose. Breakfast is without Champions.
author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr

title: Gravity's Rainbow
description: A man gets hardons for rockets. He, and a slew of other curious characters, want to know why. In brief, it's bananas!
quote: You may never get to touch the Master, but you can tickle his creatures. / Like the ballroom in St. Patrick's Cathedral, there is none in these trousers here.
author: Thomas Pynchon

title: The Strange Library
description: A curious child is held prisoner in a strange library for 96 pages.
author: Haruki Murakami

title: 2BR02B
description: In a world where people live for centuries and a strict one-in-one-out policy threatens newborn babies, a man on the verge of having triplets is forced to make hard choices.
author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr

title: Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea
description: Captive Professor Aronnax joins Captian Nemo in exploring the wonderful world beneath the waves.
author: Jules Verne

title: Kitchen Confidential
description: Bourdain exposes the juicy underbelly of the restaurant business.
author: Anthony Bourdain

title: The Magicians
description: Quentin, an unhappy 17 year old, discovers he has magical powers and hopes his new magical world will bring him happiness. It doesn't.
author: Lev Grossman

title: The Power of Now
description: Tolle writes about the importance of being present in the moment.
author: Eckhart Tolle

title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
description: Harry defeats he-who-must-not-be-named once and for all...or does he?
author: J.K. Rowling

title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince
description: Harry gets better at potions, falls in love, and goes swimming in the ocean with Dumbles.
author: J.K. Rowling

title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
description: Harry forms an army, befriends a giant, and has relationship problems with his new Headmistress.
author: J.K. Rowling

title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
description: Politics get worse and things get darker.
author: J.K. Rowling

title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
description: Politics get bad and things get dark.
author: J.K. Rowling

title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
description: A better version of the first book.
author: J.K. Rowling

title: Harry Potter and the Philsopher's Stone
description: Harry learns he is a wizard.
author: J.K. Rowling

title: God Bless You, Dr Kevorkian
description: Vonnegut undergoes several guided near-death experiences so as to hold interviews with deceased people at the threshold of the pearly gates.
author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr

title: Catching the Big Fish
description: David Lynch's brief thoughts on many topics.
author: David Lynch

title: Twin Peaks: The Final Dossier
description: The aftermath and explanation of Twin Peaks: The Return.
author: Mark Frost

title: The Secret Diary of Laura Palmer
description: The diary of the murdered former prom queen from Twin Peaks, Washington.
author: Jennifer Lynch

title: It
description: The only thing to fear is alien clowns in the drains.
author: Stephen King

title: Fahrenheit 451
description: A fireman becomes interested in knowing what's in the bible.
quote: He felt his smile slide away, melt, fold over, and down on itself like a tallow skin, like the stuff of a fantastic candle burning too long and now collapsing and now blown out. Darkness. He was not happy. He was not happy. He said the words to himself. He recognized this as the true state of affairs. He wore his happiness like a mask and the girl had run off across the lawn with the mask and there was no way of going to knock on her door and ask for it back.
author: Ray Bradbury

title: The Secret History of Twin Peaks
description: From the tribes that settled in TP before it was called that, to Louis & Clark, to UFO's and Kennedy; it's all connected.
author: Mark Frost

title: American Gods
description: What if immigrants brought their gods with them to America and the gods fought in a giant Battle Royale
author: Neil Gaiman

title: The Tale of Beren and Lúthien
description: If you thought the story of Aragorn and Arwen was romantic, wait till you get a load of this.
author: J.R.R. Tolkien

title: The Wonderful Wizard of Oz
description: A young girl sees in color for the first time.
author: L. Frank Baum

title: The Futurist Cookbook
description: Did you know Fascism has its own cuisine?
author: Fillippo Tommaso Martinetti

title: Cinder
description: Cinderella...IN SPACE!
author: Marissa Meyer

title: The Diary of a Young Girl
description: The Holocaust was unbelievably horrible.
author: Anne Frank

title: The Adventures of Pinocchio
description: A marionette comes to life and gets into lots of trouble.
author: Carlo Collodi

title: A Supposedly Fun Thing I'll Never Do Again
description: Short essays from a great mind.
author: David Foster Wallace

title: James and the Giant Peach
description: A boy finds bugs growing inside an oversized stone fruit.
author: Roald Dahl

title: Welcome to the Monkey House
description: Billy the Poet, a drug free 'Nothinghead', kidnaps a woman and convinces her to stop taking her government mandated 'ethical birth control' pills.
author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr

title: The God Delusion
description: A pretentious jerk makes good points.
author: Richard Dawkins

title: Patience
description: Time travel, revenge, and beautiful imagery.
author: Daniel Clowes

title: Hell's Angels
description: Gonzo journalism with a biker gang.
author: Hunter S. Thompson

title: A Clockwork Orange
description: The exploits of ultra-violent youth in a dystopian near future. Also the reason eggs are now called 'eggie weggies'.
quote: Civilized my syphilised yarbles.
author: Anthony Burgess

title: The Sound and the Fury
description: The slow downfall of an old money, white, southern family.
author: William Faulkner

title: Nineteen Eighty-Four
description: Don't read if you hate rats!
author: George Orwell

title: Mostly Harmless
description: Arthur discovers his talent for making sandwiches and Earth is destroyed.
author: Douglas Adams

title: So Long, and Thanks for All the Fish
description: Arthur reads God's final message to its creation.
author: Douglas Adams

title: Life, the Universe and Everything
description: Arthur learns about the history of Cricket.
author: Douglas Adams

title: The Restaurant at the End of the Universe
description: Arthur considers having the beef for dinner.
author: Douglas Adams

title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
description: Arthur learns the meaning of life, the universe and everything.
author: Douglas Adams

title: The Woman in Black
description: A ghost haunts a young man.
author: Susan Hill

title: Charlie and the Great Glass Elevator
description: There is a good reason this wonderful clusterfuck was not made into a film.
author: Roald Dahl

title: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory
description: The story we all know, in printed on candy.
author: Roald Dahl

title: Delusions of Gender
description: She disproves many poorly executed scientific studies which claim that there are genetic differences between female and male brains.
author: Cordelia Fine

title: A Midsummer Night's Dream
description: Marriage, faries, amateure actors, and a jackass.
author: William Shakespeare

title: The Silmarillion
description: A dense history of middle earth, from the beginning up until the hobbit.
author: J.R.R. Tolkien

title: Frankenstein
description: It's true, the book is better.
author: Mary Shelley

title: The Pale King
description: In an age of increasing automation, one tax official seeks to build a team of investigators with special powers.
quote: To be, in a word, unborable.... It is the key to modern life. If you are immune to boredom, there is literally nothing you cannot accomplish.
author: David Foster Wallace

title: Free Culture
description: Copyright law in America is bad for creativity and is controlled in large part by Disney.
author: Lawrence Lessig

title: The Case for Socialism
description: A dated argument for why Socialism and Marxist ideals are worthy of adhering to.
author: Paul Foot

title: The Grapes of Wrath
description: When humans can't rely on the government or corporations to take care of them, they have to rely on other humans.
author: John Steinbeck

title: Bowie
subtitle: A Biography
description: A genderless alien comes to earth and emits strange, hypnotizing sounds for fifty years.
author: Marc Spitz

title: Vertical Motion
description: Short stories of surreal events in mundane spaces.
author: Can Xue

title: The Metamorphosis
description: A man turns into a bug and his family is unsure of how to handle the situation.
author: Franz Kafka

title: Matilda
description: A very bright girl with special powers overcomes numerous mean adults.
author: Roald Dahl

title: Hangmen
description: On the day the death penalty was banned, an out of work hangman may have just found one more job before he hangs up his noose forever.
author: Martin McDonagh

title: Adventures of Huckleberry Finn
description: A poor boy and an escaped slave go on an adventure down the Mississippi River.
author: Mark Twain

title: Through the Looking-Glass
description: A young girl ingests a second large dose of LSD.
author: Lewis Carroll

title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland
description: A young girl ingests a large dose of LSD.
author: Lewis Carroll

title: The Wapshot Scandal
description: A quirky Massachusetts family adapts to life in the atomic age.
quote: Coverly cleared the walks after breakfast. The loud ringing of his shovel on the paving had a singular and a foolish charm, as if this rude music, this simple task, evoked the spirit of Leander in a happier role than he had seemed damned to play out in the wreckage of the old house on River Street. The blinding light on the snow seemed to ring again and again around the boundaries of the village like the vibrations of a rubbed water glass, but even that early in the day the brilliance of the light could be seen to shift, to be the lights of one of the shortest days of the year.
author: John Cheever

title: And Then
description: A young man is caught between Japanese and Western ideals at the turn of the 20th century.
author: Soseki Natsume

title: The Sun Also Rises
description: In the aftermath of WWI, a group of artists wander Western Europe seeking peace, meaning, and thrills.
author: Ernest Hemingway

title: Modernist Cuisine: V.1
subtitle: History & Fundamentals
description: The history of science in cooking.
author: Nathan Myhrvold

title: Cat's Cradle
description: A small rogue Caribbean island with a quirky religion gains a weapon of total annihilation.
author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr

title: As You Like It
description: The pinnacle of Shakespeare's comedy.
author: William Shakespeare

title: Bicycle Diaries
description: David Byrne travels the world with a bicycle.
author: David Byrne

title: Dracula
description: No adaptation does a better job at telling this story than the book that started it all.
quote: I sometimes think we must be all mad and that we shall wake to sanity in strait-waistcoats.
author: Bram Stoker

title: In Cold Blood
description: Capote's account of investigating brutal murders in a small town in Kansas.
quote: The village of Holcomb stands on the high wheat plains of western Kansas, a lonesome area that other Kansans call 'out there.' . . .The land is flat, the views are awesomely extensive; horses, herds of cattle, a white cluster of grain elevators rising as gracefully as Greek temples are visible long before a traveler reaches them.
author: Truman Capote

title: Showa (1926-1939: A History of Japan)
description: Historical manga telling of the build up to Japan's invasion of Manchuria from the perspective of a Japanese boy.
author: Shigeru Mizuki

title: The Delicate Prey
description: Tales of normal people in sordid situations.
quote: When they had gone the Moungari fell silent, to wait through the cold hours for the sun that would bring first warmth, then heat, thirst, fire, visions. The next night he did not know where he was, did not feel the cold. The wind blew dust along the ground into his mouth as he sang.
author: Paul Bowles

title: Breakfast at Tiffany's
description: The tale of a country girl Geisha living in 1940's Manhattan.
author: Truman Capote

title: Venus on the Half-Shell
description: A pulp Science fiction written by a fictional author found in the works of Kurt Vonnegut.
author: Kilgore Trout

title: Post Office
description: The detailed life of a slob and abuser who can barely hold it together.
author: Charles Bukowski

title: Naked Lunch
description: A dream state of drugs, sex, and undercover agents.
author: William S. Burroughs

title: Slaughterhouse-Five
description: A semi-autobiographical story of sudden space-teleportation, near-death experiences, and passificism on the battlefield.
author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr

title: The Hobbit
description: In a hole in the ground there lived a hobbit.
author: J.R.R. Tolkien

title: Bored of the Rings
description: It's a travesty, but sort of a funny one.
quote: This ring, no other, is made by the Elves. Who'd pawn their own mother to get it themselves. Ruler of creeper, mortal and scallop, This is a sleeper that packs quite a wallop. If broken or busted it cannot be remade. If found, send to Sorhed. (The postage is prepaid.)
author: Henry N. Beard

title: On The Road
description: Driving in cars and getting into trouble.
author: Jack Kerouac

title: Singing Out
subtitle: An Oral History of America's Folk Music Revivals
description: Woody Guthrie was a real interesting person.
author: David King Dunway

title: The Outsiders
description: Greasy hair, switchblades, and leather jackets.
author: S. E. Hinton

title: Inherent Vice
description: In the twilight of the free loving 60's and with the return of law, order, and corruption, one dirty-footed detective walks the line between the cop world and the pull of the universe.
author: Thomas Pynchon

title: First Light
description: The story of the building of (at the time) the world's largest telescope.
author: Richard Preston

title: V for Vendetta
description: The whole reason for the resurgence of the Guy Fawkes mask boom.
author: Alan Moore

title: Watchmen
description: A group of retired superheroes must reunite to save the world.
author: Alan Moore

title: Batman: The Killing Joke
description: Some good Batman reading.
author: Alan Moore

title: The Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin
description: He was smart, but also just a man.
author: Benjamin Franklin

title: Galápagos
description: A global financial crisis and near human-wide infertility allows the Galapagos to become an isolated island of evolution for the second time.
author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr

title: Running the books
description: A memoir of a prison librarian.
author: Avi Steinberg

title: The Phantom Tollbooth
description: An unhappy boy gets stuck in a land of puns and tyranny.
author: Norton Juster

title: Switch Bitch
description: 4 stories of sex, murder, and conniving.
author: Roald Dahl

title: The Man Who Folded Himself
description: A person time travels over and over and befriends many versions of themself.
author: David Gerrold

title: Animal Farm
description: The 1917 Russian Revolution with animals.
author: George Orwell

title: The Names
description: A series of murders in Greece all seem to be connected by names.
author: Don DeLillo

title: Heart of Darkness
description: One man travels into the jungle on a mission to find and kill another.
author: Joseph Conrad

title: A Field Guide to Lucid Dreaming
description: This will teach you how to lucid dream.
author: Dylan Tuccillo

title: A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man
description: A young Irishman becomes disillusioned.
author: James Joyce

title: My Uncle Oswald
description: Oswald and his partner travel around Europe in an attempt to retrieve the sperm of powerful, rich and artistic men.
author: Roald Dahl

title: The Farewell Waltz
description: A group of citizens are drawn together in a small spa town in Czechoslovakia in early 1970s.
author: Milan Kundera

title: Point Omega
description: I really don't have any idea what this was about.
author: Don Delillo

title: White Noise
description: Citizens deal with the fallout from an 'airborne toxic event'.
author: Don DeLillo

title: Cosmicomics
description: Stories of love during the shaping of the universe.
quote: And in this self-expression I put all the thoughts I had about her, I released the anger she made me feel, my amorous way of thinking about her, my determination to exist for her, the desire for me to be me, and for her to be her, and the love for myself that I put in my love for her, all the things that could be said only in that conch shell wound into a spiral.
author: Italo Calvino

title: Invisible Cities
description: An explorer relays tales of impossible cities to a skeptical king.
author: Italo Calvino

title: Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas
description: Vegas on drugs.
author: Hunter S. Thompson

title: God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater
description: A misunderstood man seeks to become a good father.
quote: It was through the criss-crossed shadows of harpoons that Amanita Buntline and Caroline Rosewater now shuffled. Amanita led the way, set the tone, examined the stock greedily, barbarously. As for the nature of the stock: it was everything a cold wife might demand of an impotent husband upon rising from a scalding bath.
author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr

title: Darkly Dreaming Dexter
description: A likeable serial killer who spares the innocent almost gets caught.
author: Jeff Lindsay

title: Scott Pilgrim
description: A lazy guy has to battle a host of ex's for the chance to date the woman of his dreams.
author: Bryan Lee O'Malley

title: Biography of Thomas Jefferson
description: A bit about the Founding Father.
author: Fawn M. Brodie

title: Steve Jobs
description: The biography of vegan fruit enthusiast who lived on another planet.
author: Walter Isaacson

title: Whip Smart
description: A former dominatrix tells her tale.
author: Melissa Febos

title: Sex, Drugs, and Cocoa Puffs
subtitle: A Low Culture Manifesto
description: Pop culture critique of the 00's.
author: Chuck Klosterman

title: The City of Dreaming Books
description: A literature enthused dinosaur gets lost in an underworld of bizarre books.
author: Walter Moers

title: Flowers for Algernon
description: A man with cognitive delay takes an experimental drug that makes him a genius.
author: Daniel Keyes

title: Holidays on Ice
description: The wacky life of an interesting human.
